definition: Conjunctivitis, also known as pink eye, is an inflammation or infection of the conjunctiva, the thin, transparent layer covering the white part of the eye and the inner eyelids.
symptoms: Redness in one or both eyes
Itching or burning sensation in the eyes
Watery or discharge from the eyes (may be clear, yellow, or green)
Crusting of eyelids or lashes, especially in the morning
Sensitivity to light
Feeling like something is in the eye
causes: Viral infection (e.g., adenovirus, common in viral conjunctivitis)
Bacterial infection (e.g., Staphylococcus or Streptococcus)
Allergies (e.g., pollen, dust, or pet dander)
Irritants (e.g., smoke, chemicals, or contact lenses)
Fungal infections (rare)
risk_factors: Exposure to someone with viral or bacterial conjunctivitis
Seasonal allergies or allergic conditions
Contact lens use, especially if hygiene is poor
Crowded settings (e.g., schools, daycare)
Weakened immune system
Recent upper respiratory infection
treatment: Apply a clean, warm compress to the eyes several times a day to relieve discomfort
Use over-the-counter artificial tears or lubricating eye drops to reduce irritation (avoid drops that reduce redness)
Clean eyelids gently with tap water or a mild, non-irritating soap to remove discharge
For bacterial conjunctivitis, use antibiotic eye drops or ointment as prescribed by a doctor
For allergic conjunctivitis, use antihistamine or anti-inflammatory eye drops as recommended
Avoid touching or rubbing the eyes to prevent worsening or spreading
Discontinue contact lens use until the condition resolves
prevention: Wash hands frequently with soap and water, especially after touching eyes or face
Avoid sharing towels, washcloths, or pillowcases with others
Do not share eye makeup, contact lenses, or eye drops
Clean and disinfect contact lenses properly, and replace them as recommended
Avoid allergens if you have allergic conjunctivitis (e.g., stay indoors during high pollen days)
Practice good hygiene in crowded settings to reduce infection risk
